reviewText: I keep watching it over and over...each time picking up something I missed the previous time. There is hope!!

With a panel of six participants a thorough explanation is presented in this video of the highly addictive nature of crystal meth. The behaviors are explained and family involvement is discussed. The denial and fear from a parents perspective is shared as well as some options for parents to help themselves.

The video shares the importance of the spiritual aspect which can be vital to long-term recovery. It reminds us that everyone is affected by a family members meth use and it stresses the importance of each family member engaging in their own recovery.

I would highly recommend this video to any family members or friends of someone who is struggling with drug use. It gives solid information from an experienced panel about crystal meth which can be applied to any drug use, as well as reminds us that there is hope. Recovery is possible! Cathy Taughinbaugh, author of Parents to PhDs: 28 interviews with people who share heartache, wisdom and healing from first-hand experience with substance use disorder. www.cathytaughinbaugh.com

This video contains very important information. You many not be struggle with a Meth addiction but you will get very valuable information on any addiction you are dealing with. A must watch for anyone who needs addiction information.

3-Minute Trailer for "Why Don't They Just Quit METH? Families need help too." Changing Lives produces materials for families who are dealing with addiction (often)for the first time. Similar to our first DVD "Why Don't They Just Quit? What families and friends need to know about addiction and recovery" this is a Roundtable Discussion, informational in nature and designed help educate friends, employers and family members. It was NOT developed for entertainment value (we are NOT competing with movie/TV resources such as National Geographic or A&E) and we want to make sure our viewers have clear expectations. Yes, meth addicts DO recover and families can and do get better.
